stem: The nurse is auscultating breath sounds. Match each adventitious lung sound with its correct description and likely associated condition.

columns.text: Popping sound (like Velcro) on inspiration; Heart Failure/Atelectasis
High-pitched, musical squeaking on expiration; Asthma
High-pitched, crowing sound on inspiration; Airway Obstruction / Croup
Grating or creaking sound (like leather); Pleurisy

rationale.correct: Accurate lung sound identification guides treatment (e.g., Diuretics vs. Bronchodilators). (r1) Crackles = Fluid/Atelectasis. (r2) Wheezes = Narrowed tubes. (r3) Rhonchi = Sludge in big tubes. (r4) Stridor = Emergency airway tightening. (r5) Rub = Inflamed pleura.
rationale.incorrect: Rhonchi can often clear with a cough, whereas crackles usually do not.
clinicalPearls: Stridor is the highest priority adventitious sound; it indicates impending total airway occlusion.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember: Crackles are 'popping' (Static). Rhonchi are 'snoring' (Rumbling). In NGN, check if the sound 'clears with coughing'â€”that's usually Rhonchi.

reviewUnits.heading: Respiratory Assessment Fundamentals
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must auscultate all lung fields (Anterior, Posterior, Lateral). Use the diaphragm of the stethoscope and instruct the client to take deep breaths through their mouth.
